section.title: Performance
section.p: Depending on the size of your document, can magically decrease your publishing times by up to 70%This figure only holds for relatively small documents where the overhead of creating the JVM, loading classes, compiling XSLT stylesheets, and so on takes up more time than the actual processing. If your document takes 30 minutes to process now, it won't take 9 minutes with : more like 28 minutes, most likely. after the first run. The difference is more noticeable with small or medium documents.

note.p: You must have the Gradle Daemon enabled to get the performance benefit.

section.p: The performance improvement is due to the Gradle Daemon, which effectively removes the JVM warmup time.

If you're feeling adventurous and you have a multi-project build, you can also try Gradle's --parallel option to build your documents in parallel and speed builds up even more. However, since DITA-OT isn't fully thread-safe, your builds might become unreliable.

section.title: Incremental builds
section.p: checks whether your source files have changedIt currently checks whether any of the files under the directory where your source file is have changed. If you have files outside that directory, can't detect changes to those files. and only runs DITA-OT if they have (or if you force it to by passing the --rerun-tasks option).

If you're publishing a large document set, you can set up a
multi-project build and speed up the feedback cycle by publishing only those documents that have changed.

section.title: Continuous builds
section.p: You can also use Gradle's continuous build feature option to tell DITA-OT to automatically republish your document when it changes:
section.codeblock: $ gradle --continuous ... Waiting for changes to input files of tasks... (ctrl-d to exit) Change detected, executing build... ...
section.p: This is especially useful when writing a small document or a single topic because it lets you see the effects of your changes fairly quickly.
